Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of ABThera vs. Barker's Vacuum Pack in Reducing Systemic Inflammation

Participants.evidence: Forty-five adults undergoing abbreviated laparotomy were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to ABThera (n=23) or Barker's vacuum pack (n=22)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine if the ABThera temporary abdominal closure device reduces systemic inflammation compared to Barker's vacuum pack.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the difference in plasma IL-6 concentration at 24 and 48 hours post-application.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment via a dedicated website.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Forty-five adults undergoing abbreviated laparotomy were randomised 1:1 to ABThera (n=23) or Barker's vacuum pack (n=22) between September 29, 2011, and December 9, 2012.

Number_Analysed.evidence: No significant differences were observed in adverse events, including enterocutaneous fistula formation and intra-abdominal hypertension.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 90-day mortality was lower in the ABThera group (HR 0.32, 95% CI 0.11–0.93, p=0.04).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences were observed in adverse events, including enterocutaneous fistula formation and intra-abdominal hypertension.

Funding.evidence: The trial was funded by institutional grants.
